title: Ticket #3477: Keypairs of EC2 jobs may not be cleaned up.
description:
It is permissible for an EC2 job to go on hold without deleting its keypair. (The keypair may belong to the user; or the user may wish to use the keypair; or the keypair should be left active to avoid invalidating a spot request.)

When such a job enters recovery, we correctly avoid recreating the keypair. However, we do not set the flag which marks the keypair as created; so when the job eventually leaves the queue, we don't clean the keypair up.

It is presently problematic to determine from the job ad if we created the keypair. This fix will have three parts:

(1) Prevent the user from specifying both a keypair name and a filename for saving the created keypair. Since this options are mutually exclusive, this won't cause any problems.

(2) Now that we know both keypair name and filename can be set only when we created a keypair, use that information to determine when to remove a keypair from the cloud.

(3) If and only if the job we see in GM_DELETE is exiting the queue (for good), delete the on-disk copy of the keypair. This allows the user to (potentially) access the instance started by the held job.
remarks:
2013-Feb-20 16:07:19 by jfrey:
Code Review

  • I think the keypair cleanup code in GM_DELETE is too aggressive. When is it OK to destroy a keypair on the EC2 server without interfering with instances that want to use that keypair? It's entirely possible for a job to end up in GM_DELETE state after the instance has been requested but before the server has started it, and for the job to be healthly and recoverable and will be seen by the gridmanager in the near future.

2013-Feb-21 15:13:05 by tlmiller:
After discussion with Jaime, the code will be amended to be much less aggressive: only remove keypairs from the server under the same conditions as from disk. Discussion, however, revealed the problem discussed in the child ticket (#3508).
